main_definition: Lord can refer to a noble person, particularly in historical contexts, or denote authority or control over something.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A title of nobility used before one's name by men who hold hereditary titles such as duke, marquess, earl, viscount and baron. It is also a term used to address or refer to someone with considerable social status.
meanings_and_examples.example: During the medieval period, lords would often rule over their lands on behalf of the king.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A male god in various religious beliefs; an entity who exercises control and power in a spiritual sense.
meanings_and_examples.example: In Hinduism, Indra is considered one of the major lords or gods.

meanings_and_examples.definition: One with whom one has a close relationship, often used to show respect or deference towards someone
meanings_and_examples.example: Please excuse my lord; he's not feeling well today.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A person who controls and governs another, especially in an oppressive or authoritative manner.
meanings_and_examples.example: The lord of the manor had absolute power over his tenants.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A large sum of money that is a financial burden to one's estate.
meanings_and_examples.example: He was in debt up to his neck, owing a vast amount of gold coins; it weighed down the lord of his kingdom.
